author: Cadena SER
title: Trabajadores municipales de Cambre vuelven a concentrarse para denunciar su "penosa" situación | Política | Cadena SER
text:
Trabajadores municipales de Cambre vuelven a concentrarse para denunciar su "penosa" situación
Sada lleva a pleno las obras en el Río Maior. Culleredo propone un corredor verde que compense la huella de carbono por la presencia del aeropuerto
Vanesa Paz, delegada de la CIG en el Concello de Cambre
El código iframe se ha copiado en el portapapeles
A Coruña
La situación de los trabajadores municipales de Cambre sigue enquistada y este jueves han vuelto a concentrarse ante el Concello para exigir mejoras en sus condiciones. Insisten en que la valoración de sus puestos data del 1999 sin actualizaciones. Un contexto que definen como "penoso" por la "escasez extrema" de personal.
Señalan que cada vez que hay una baja no se cubre y lo hace el tiempo de espera es de varios meses. Algo que cada vez afecta más al funcionamiento del ayuntamiento y a los vecinos que recurren a servicios sociales. Vanessa Paz es representante de los trabajadores.
Mientras tanto, el gobierno municipal informa que llevará al Pleno el pago de facturas y el cambio en la Relación de Puestos de Trabajo, que permitiría dispner de nuevos técnicos en diferentes área. Dos propuestas que fueron rechazadas anteriormente al no disponer de mayoría suficiente.
Sada lleva a pleno las obras en el Río Maior
El Concello de Sada celebra a las ocho de la tarde un Pleno Ordinario en el que someterá a votación el convenio con Augas de Galicia para acometer las obras de apertura y naturalización del Río Maior. La intención es reducir el riesgo de inundaciones creando canales de alivio en los márgenes del río.
El alcalde Benito Portela considera que se trata de unas obras necesarias y que deberían tener apoyo del Gobierno. De cara al Pleno de hoy pide a los grupos un acuerdo unánime.
En la misma sesión plenario el Partido Popular pedirá explicaciones por el acopio de residuos en una obra en el barrio de Fontán, protegido por Patrimonio. El Concello asegura que todavía está sin recepcionar y que se encuentra en un terreno vallado.
Culleredo propone un corredor verde que compense la huella de carbono por la presencia del aeropuerto
El Gobierno Local de Culleredo quiere crear un corredor verde desde Almeiras a Vilaboa pasando por O Burgo. Con arbolado autóctono, láminas de agua para la fauna y limpieza selectiva de la vegetación. El alcalde, José Ramón Rioboo, considera que este nuevo espacio ambiental puede compensar la huella de carbono por la presencia, a pocos metros, del aeropuerto.
Le ha trasladado esta semana la propuesta a la Fundación Biodiversidad, del Ministerio para la Transición Ecológica. La idea del Concello es promover acuerdos con los propietarios de montes, actualmente sin otros usos, para una gestión adecuada del territorio. Considera que así se generarían "entornos que fomentarán la biodiversidad facilitando su empleo para la ciudadanía". Rioboo acusa al PP de mantener una "estela de embarrar y de crear "falsedades constantes".
Culleredo pide una piscina olímpica en el recinto de Acea de Ama
El Concello de Culleredo insta a la Xunta a suspender el proceso de licitación del complejo deportivo de Acea de Ama. El pleno de esta semana ha aprobado una iniciativa del BNG con esta petición que ha sido respaldada por el PSOE y Alternativa dos Veciños y el voto en contra del PP. Demandan una nueva piscina de dimensiones olímpicas para cubrir las demandas de la comarca. La actual se queda pequeña, según fuentes municipales.
Hay clubes de natación de Culleredo que pagan hasta 8 mil euros por utilizar las instalaciones y reclaman una piscina que permita la celebración de competiciones oficiales en la comarca y completar el circuito de piscinas olímpicas de Galicia.El Consello de la Xunta ha aprobado recientemente la licitación de la gestión del complejo deportivo de Acea de Ama por un período de 20 años con una previsión de ingresos de 50 millones de euros durante el tiempo que dure el contrato.

author: ESPN
title: Cristiano Ronaldo marca el gol 900 en su carrera - ESPN
text: El delantero suma 900 goles en 1,238 partidos oficiales, con una media de casi 0.73 tantos por encuentro El delantero portugués, [Cristiano Ronaldo](https://www.espn.com.mx/futbol/jugador/_/id/22774/cristiano-ronaldo), alcanzó los 900 goles en su carrera este jueves, al marcar el segundo tanto de [Portugal ](https://www.espn.com.mx/futbol/equipo/_/id/482/portugal)en el partido de la [Nations League](/futbol/liga/_/nombre/uefa.nations) ante Croacia. El gol, un remate con el pie derecho desde el corazón del área tras asistencia de Nuno Mendes, supone un hito más en la carrera de récord del jugador. El delantero suma 900 goles en 1,238 partidos oficiales, con una media de casi 0.73 tantos por encuentro, que ha marcado con las camisetas de Sporting (5), del Manchester United (145), del Real Madrid (450), del Juventus (101) y del Al-Nassr (67). A su periplo en estos clubes se suman los 131 tantos que ha firmado con la selección de Portugal. La afición lusa recibió el gol de [Cristiano](https://www.espn.com.mx/futbol/jugador/_/id/22774/cristiano-ronaldo) con su ya famoso "Siuuu" y coreó el nombre del delantero de Madeira, que para celebrarlo se tiró al suelo en la línea de fondo con las manos en la cara y una sonrisa.

author: Gitty Aiden
title: Taco Bell Manager Saves Choking Baby: A Hero’s Story in Pennsylvania
text: A Taco Bell manager in Bucks County is being hailed a hero for her brave actions that saved the life of a choking baby. The incident occurred in Richboro, Pennsylvania on Saturday. The heart-stopping moment was captured on surveillance video, showing a distressed mother in the drive-thru holding her baby. Suddenly, she jumps and screams for help, realizing that her baby has stopped breathing. Without hesitation, the manager of the Taco Bell rushes to their aid. She immediately starts performing CPR on the infant, while another worker quickly dials 911 for emergency assistance. The manager’s swift response and knowledge of life-saving techniques proved crucial in this terrifying situation. Remarkably, she revealed that she knew what to do because she had experienced a similar incident with her own daughter when she was younger. Despite her heroic actions, the humble manager insists that she is not a hero. She believes that she happened to be in the right place at the right time to help a fellow mother in need. Potential Future Trends and Implications Increased Need for First Aid Training This heartwarming story serves as a reminder of the importance of first aid training, particularly for individuals working in public-facing roles. As more incidents like this occur, there may be a growing demand for companies to provide comprehensive first aid training to their employees. In addition to basic first aid, specialized training in infant and child CPR could become a requirement for employees in industries such as food service, retail, and hospitality. Furthermore, communities may come together to promote and encourage first aid education, partnering with local organizations to offer affordable or free training to the general public. This would empower individuals to respond effectively during emergencies and potentially save lives. Recognition and Support for Everyday Heroes This incident highlights the valor that can be found within ordinary individuals. The actions of this Taco Bell manager showcase the bravery and selflessness that can often be overlooked in our society. With stories like this gaining attention, there may be a shift in cultural norms, where everyday heroes are celebrated and recognized for their exceptional acts. This recognition could come in the form of appreciative gestures from the community, commendations from their employers, or even official honors from local government entities. This increased recognition and support for everyday heroes could have a positive impact on morale, encouraging individuals to step up and assist others in need without hesitation. Emphasis on Workplace Safety and Preparedness In light of this incident, businesses may revisit their safety protocols and emergency preparedness procedures. It serves as a reminder that emergencies can happen anywhere, and it is crucial for organizations to establish clear guidelines and training programs to ensure the safety of both employees and customers. Workplaces may consider conducting regular safety drills, providing employees with specific guidelines for responding to different emergencies, and ensuring that first aid kits and equipment are readily available. This proactive approach can significantly minimize the risk of accidents and enhance overall safety and well-being within the organization. Conclusion This heartwarming incident involving a Taco Bell manager’s heroic actions emphasizes the importance of first aid training, the recognition of everyday heroes, and the need for workplace safety and preparedness. As we move forward, it is crucial for individuals, businesses, and communities to prioritize these aspects in order to create a safer and more supportive society. author: Kiara Alfonseca, ABC News
title: 'Really scary': Families brace for impact of transgender youth care ban in Ohio – WHIO TV 7 and WHIO Radio
text: NEW YORK — Astrid Burkle, a 10-year-old transgender girl who lives in Ohio, said she wishes she "could have a normal life." Her desire for normalcy -- a life of baking cookies with her grandmother, singing with her friends in the local choir, and going on field trips -- is shrouded by impending anti-transgender legislation passed by the statehouse. "It's been really frustrating at times," Astrid told ABC News in an interview alongside her family. "Because there's just so many people out there who are just really mean." Families across the state are bracing for the impact of a bill that would restrict certain transgender rights for minors. Ohio House Bill 68 is comprised of two acts: the "Save Adolescents from Experimentation Act," which would ban transgender minors from receiving gender-affirming care, and the "Save Women's Sports Act," which would prevent transgender girls from taking part in girls' and women's sports. An exception in this bill allows hormone-based care and surgery for intersex and cisgender youth. Republican Gov. Mike DeWine has yet to announce whether he will sign or veto the legislation – but more than three-fifths of legislators have voted in favor of the bill so far and can override his veto. Astrid's mother, Alicia Burkle said Astrid has been receiving strictly mental health care services in recent years. Therapy, Astrid said, offers a "safe space" to talk through her experiences. However, the restrictions placed on Astrid's future choices for care have the family questioning their options. "Just because you've said that you're not going to allow us to get the care here in Ohio doesn't mean we're suddenly going to stop getting the care for our kids," said Alicia Burkle. She continued, "We trust the science, we trust her healthcare providers. And so we're going to do what we have to do and whether that is travel out of state to get it, whether it's leave the state and move -- that's what we'll do." Burkle said her cisgender daughter is on hormone replacement therapy -- "But nobody's questioning that ... So I don't understand." Supporters of gender-affirming care restrictions believe that gender transitioning is harmful to youth. Some say patients should wait until they are older to make this kind of health decision. State Sen. Terry Johnson, who is a retired physician, argued in favor of the bill on the Senate floor. "If you don't know if something you're doing is going to hurt someone 10, 15, 20 years down the road -- or maybe even one year down the road -- don't do it," Johnson said in a Dec. 13 debate. "The medical evidence is not there to support what we're doing in the country." Critics of these laws say they prevent families and physicians from making decisions about their health care and will harm transgender youth. MORE: Federal judge blocks Idaho gender-affirming transgender care ban State Sen. Paula Hicks-Hudson argued against the bill in the Dec. 13 debate. "When we look at this legislation, let's be clear, it is not necessarily about preventing children from being exposed to these types of procedures, but it is preventing parents who are making decisions about the health care of their children," she said. "It also removes that decision for health care from professionals and parents and gives it again to government." Gender-affirming care has been called safe, effective, and medically necessary by more than 20 major national medical associations, including the American Academy of Pediatrics and the American Medical Association. Dr. Christopher Bolling, a member of the Ohio Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics, told ABC News in an interview that pediatricians and physicians are "extremely cautious" when it comes to gender-affirming care and often have many long conversations with people who are questioning their gender. This gives patients time to explore their identity and create an individualized approach to care. For youth approaching puberty, puberty blockers are a reversible form of gender-affirming care that allows children to pause puberty and explore their gender identity without the growth of permanent sex characteristics, according to physicians interviewed by ABC News. This option would be banned by the legislation. It would also ban hormone therapy, which brings physical traits in line with gender identify. Often because of gender-related discrimination and gender dysphoria, transgender youth are more likely to experience anxiety, depressed mood, and suicidal ideation and attempts, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Research shows that hormone therapy can improve the mental health of transgender adolescents and teenagers, a recent study in the New England Journal of Medicine found. The legislation has a grandfather clause that allows minors who are already on medication to continue to receive care. It's a benefit for some families in the state, including Nick Zingarelli, his wife and his teenage daughter who is already taking puberty blockers. Zingarelli raised his daughter in Cincinnati, Ohio -- but the family moved to Missouri in 2019 to be closer to his wife's family. His daughter came out as transgender in 2020 when she was still a preteen. He told ABC News that his daughter's coming out changed both everything and nothing about their family. "Obviously it changed everything in terms of having to advocate for her rights," said Zingarelli in an interview. "Missouri is a deep red state." He continued, "And when I say that nothing at all changed -- when we told friends, family, school, everybody, it was like, 'Okay, great. So these are her new pronouns. This is her name.'" Zingarelli said he met with doctors at the time who said there was nothing they could do for his daughter at her age except for counseling. "So this belief that doctors are just running to get prescriptions filled and everything else as soon as gender dysphoria is disclosed is nonsense," said Zingarelli. Zingarelli and his family later moved back to Ohio in part to escape anti-transgender legislation in Missouri that restricted trans participation in sports and gender-affirming care. They did not expect to be faced with restrictive legislation in Ohio, the place they call home, he said. For Zingarelli, the grandfather clause protecting his daughter's care is "not good enough," since it doesn't protect care in the future for children like Astrid who are not yet old enough to receive medical care. The community has been supportive of Astrid and her family, according to Astrid's father, Aaron. "We want to be able to support our communities and the state of Ohio, but like, people are going to leave," said Abs Burkle, Astrid's sister. "People are going to be hurt. They're not going to want to come back to Ohio." If you or a loved one is struggling with a mental health crisis or considering suicide, call or text 988. Copyright © 2023, ABC Audio. All rights reserved.
